titlestmt.titleproper: Solidarity International of Connecticut records CPAA 95.08
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Special Collections staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-04-18T12:53-0400

did.unittitle: Solidarity International of Connecticut records
did.abstract: Solidarity International of Connecticut (SI of CT) was a non-profit organization established in 1982 after Martial Law was imposed in Poland on December 13, 1981. SI of CT is a part of Solidarity International, a nationwide organization dedicated to the struggle for human rights and the perpetuation of the ideals of the Solidarity movement in Poland during the 1980’s and 1990’s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, legal and financial documents, minutes from meetings, pamphlets, clippings and posters related to the Connecticut chapter of Solidarity International. It also includes position papers published by various organizations. The collection was donated by attorney Richard Kosinski, one of the members, and covers years 1979- 1995.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Solidarity International (SI) was created in February of 1982 as a not for profit organization in New York. Its purpose was to “help all those dominated and/or subjugated by totalitarian systems by spreading the idea of Solidarity.” The implementation of Martial Law in Poland in December, 1981 was the inspiration for this cause. The Solidarity International of Connecticut (SI of CT) was established in 1982 also. SI mission was to provide moral and material assistance to the Polish trade unions Solidarnosc (Solidarity) and to all oppressed by totalitarian systems. SI did not represent Solidarity however it maintained close contact with the Solidarity Abroad Office located in Brussels, Belgium. SI activities included organizing and coordinating direct assistance to Solidarity and to families of imprisoned workers and activists. The program was called "Family to Family" and Connecticut chapter was especially active in the program. Mrs. Maria Zub-Zdanowicz and Elizabeth Wasiutynski were the main coordinators of this effort. SI of CT organized many events to increase public awareness about Solidarity and the Martial Law that was imposed on Polish people. Among others they organized public rallies and protests, lectures and seminars, press releases and interviews, published and distributed pamphlets and letters.Solidarity International of Connecticut organized and actively participated in worldwide organization called the Conference of Solidarity Support Organizations (CSSO). SI and SI of CT published their newsletters.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Solidarity International of Connecticut records (CPAA 95-08). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For additional information please see the following collections: Andre B. Blaszczynski Papers (CPAA 87-105) Ewa Slusarek Papers (CPAA 93-04) Ludmil A. Chotkowski Papers (CPAA 90-14) Elizabeth Wasiutynski Papers (CPAA 91-03) Irene Dubicka Morawska Papers (CPAA 93-03)
